Proceedings.
What is stated in clause (8) about taking action under the Federal law?

Nothing shall bar the taking of action under the Federal law in relation to the offence, if any, committed while in office by the President or Vice-President, Chief Justice of Nepal or a Judge of the Supreme Court of Nepal, member of the Judicial Council, chief or official of a Constitutional Body who is relieved of office upon the passage of a motion of impeachment under this Article.
What happens to a person who is relieved of office on the passage of a motion of impeachment under clause (1) or (2)?

A person who is relieved of office on the passage of a motion of impeachment under clause (1) or (2) shall not be entitled to obtain any facility accruing from such office and to be appointed or nominated to any public office in the future.
What is mentioned in clause (9) about facilities accruing from an office?
A person who is relieved of office on the passage of a motion of impeachment under clause (1) or (2) shall not be entitled to obtain any facility accruing from such office.
What is stated in clause (10) about other matters relating to impeachment?
Other matters relating to impeachment shall be as provided for in the Federal law.
Who are the individuals mentioned in clause (8) who can be subject to action under the Federal law?

The President or Vice-President, Chief Justice of Nepal or a Judge of the Supreme Court of Nepal, member of the Judicial Council, chief or official of a Constitutional Body who is relieved of office upon the passage of a motion of impeachment under this Article.
What is the penalty for an unauthorized person present or voting in the Federal Parliament or its committee?

The person shall, by order of the person chairing the meeting, be fined with a sum of five thousand rupees for each instance of such presence or voting, and such fine shall be recovered as a government due.
What is the freedom of speech in both Houses of the Federal Parliament?
There shall be full freedom of speech in both Houses of the Federal Parliament.
Can a member of the Federal Parliament be arrested, detained or prosecuted in any court for anything expressed or any vote cast by him or her in the House?
No member shall be arrested, detained or prosecuted in any court for anything expressed or any vote cast by him or her in the House.
What is the power of each House of the Federal Parliament to regulate and decide its internal business?
Each House of the Federal Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have full power to regulate and decide its internal business.
Who has full power to regulate and decide its internal business?
Constitution
What is the concerned House?
the concerned House
What is the exclusive right of the concerned House?
the exclusive right to decide whether or not any of its proceedings is regular or irregular
Where no question shall be raised in any court in this behalf?
In this behalf
What is stated in clause (3) about comments about proceedings of any House of the Federal Parliament?

No comment shall be made about the good faith concerning any proceeding of any House of the Federal Parliament, and no publication and broadcasting of any kind shall be made about anything said by any member, intentionally distorting or misinterpreting the meaning of the speech.
What is the application of the provisions in clauses (1) and (3)?
The provisions of clauses (1) and (3) shall also apply to other persons who are entitled to participate in the meetings of the House than the members of the Federal Parliament.
What is prohibited in clause (3) regarding publications and broadcastings about anything said by any member?
No publication and broadcasting of any kind shall be made about anything said by any member, intentionally distorting or misinterpreting the meaning of the speech.
Who does the prohibition in clause (4) apply to?
The provisions of clauses (1) and (3) shall also apply to other persons who are entitled to participate in the meetings of the House than the members of the Federal Parliament.
What is the prohibition in clause (1) about?
No comment shall be made about the good faith concerning any proceeding of any House of the Federal Parliament.
What is the meaning of 'House' for the purposes of clauses (1), (2), (3) and (4) in the text?
The House means the House of Representatives or the National Assembly, and includes a joint sitting or committee or joint committee of the Federal Parliament.
What is the period during which no member of the Federal Parliament can be arrested?
The period from the issuance of a notice summoning the session to its prorogation.
What is the provision regarding the arrest of a member of the Federal Parliament on a criminal charge?

Nothing in this clause shall be deemed to bar the arresting under the Federal law of any member on a criminal charge. If any member is so arrested, the authority making such arrest shall forthwith give information.
What is the explanation provided for the clauses (1), (2), (3) and (4) in the text?

For the purposes of clauses (1), (2), (3) and (4), 'House' means the House of Representatives or the National Assembly, and includes a joint sitting or committee or joint committee of the Federal Parliament.
What is the provision regarding the arrest of a member of the Federal Parliament during the period from the issuance of a notice summoning the session to its prorogation?
No member of the Federal Parliament shall be arrested during the period from the issuance of a notice summoning the session to its prorogation.
Who shall give information about an arrest made?
The authority making such arrest shall forthwith give information thereof to the person presiding over the concerned House.
What is the exclusive right of the concerned House?
The concerned House shall have the exclusive right to decide whether any privilege has been breached.
What is the maximum term of imprisonment for contempt of any House?
The term of imprisonment for contempt of any House shall not exceed three months.
What is the maximum fine for contempt of any House?
The fine for contempt of any House shall not exceed ten thousand rupees.
Who may admonish, warn or impose a sentence of imprisonment or fine for contempt of any House?

The person presiding over the concerned House may, after a decision by the House to that effect, admonish, warn or impose a sentence of imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months or of a fine not exceeding ten thousand rupees on such person.
What action can a person take to be pardoned by the concerned House?
apologize to the satisfaction of the concerned House
What can the concerned House do if a person apologies to its satisfaction?
it may pardon, remit or commute the sentence imposed on,  him or her
What is the condition for the concerned House to pardon, remit or commute a sentence?
if such person apologies  to the satisfaction of the  concerned House
What is the provision for other matters relating to the privileges of the Federal Parliament?
Other matters relating to the privileges of the Federal Parliament  shall be as provided for in the Federal law.
What is each House of the Federal Parliament required to do?

Each House of the Federal Parliament shall frame rules to conduct its business, maintain order during its meetings and regulate the constitution, functions and procedures of the committees and procedures of the House or its committee. Until such rules are framed, the Federal Parliament shall regulate its procedures on its own.
What happens when rules are not framed for a House of the Federal Parliament?
Until such rules are framed, the Federal Parliament shall regulate its procedures on its own.
What regulates the conduct of business of the joint sitting of the Federal Parliament?
The conduct of business of the joint sitting of the Federal Parliament shall be regulated by the rules or procedures approved by the joint sitting of both Houses of the Federal Parliament.
What regulates the constitution and proceedings of the joint committee of the Federal Parliament?
The constitution and proceedings of the joint committee of the Federal Parliament shall be regulated by the rules or procedures approved by the joint sitting of both Houses of the Federal Parliament.

No discussion shall be held in either House of the Federal Parliament on any matters that may cause adverse effect on the
What matters is Federal Parliament prohibited from discussing?

Federal Parliament on any matters that may cause adverse effect on the dispensation of justice on any cases which are sub judice in any courts of Nepal and on any judicial acts done by Judges in the course of performance of their duties.

Provided that nothing in this Articl e shall be deemed to bar the expression of opinions about the conduct of a Judge during deliberations held on a motion of impeachment.
Who is responsible for appointing the Secretary General of the House of Representatives?
The President shall appoint the Secretary General of the House of Representatives on recommendation of both the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Chairperson of the National Assembly.

Representatives

What is the function of the Secretary of the National Assembly?
The functions of the Secretary of the National Assembly shall be as provided for in the Federal law.
What is the function of the Secretariat of Federal Parliament?

There shall be a Secretariat for conducting and managing the business of the Federal Parliament. The establishment of such Secretariat and other matters related thereto shall be as provided for in the Federal law.
What is the remuneration and facilities of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives?
The remuneration and facilities of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives is as provided for in the Federal law.

The remuneration and facilities of the Chairperson and the Vice - Chairperson o f the National Assembly is as provided for in the Federal law.

The remuneration and facilities of the chairpersons of the committees is as provided for in the Federal law.

The remuneration and facilities of the Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Chairperson, Vice - Chairperson, chairpersons of the committees, and members of the Federal Parliament is specified by the Government of Nepal until such law is made.

The legislative powers of the Federal Parliament shall be as enumerated in the lists of Schedule-5, Schedule-7 and Schedule-9.

Part-9  Federal Legislative Procedures

The legislative powers of the Federal Parliament are enumerated in the lists of Schedule-5, Schedule-7 and Schedule-9.

What type of Bill may be introduced in any House of the Federal Parliament?
A Bill may, subject to this Constitution, be introduced in any House of the Federal Parliament.
Where can a Money Bill be introduced?
A Money Bill shall be introduced only in the House of Representatives.
What type of Bills can be introduced only as a Government Bill?
A Money Bill and a Bill concerning a security body including the Nepal Army, Nepal Police and Armed Police Force, Nepal shall be introduced only as a Government Bill.
What is the definition of a Money Bill?

A Money Bill means a Bill concerning any or all of the following subjects: (a) the imposition, collection, abolition, remission, al teration or regulation of taxes, (b) the preservation of the Federal Consolidated Fund or any other Federal Government Fund, the deposit of moneys into and the appropriation or the withdrawal of moneys from such Funds, or the reduction, increment or cancellation of appropriations or of proposed expenditures from such Funds,
What is the cancellation of appropriations or of proposed expenditures from?
Such Funds
What does the regulation of matters relate to?
The borrowing of money or the giving of guarantee by the Government of Nepal
What pertains to the amendment of the?
The Government of Nepal
What matters are regulated in the text?
Matters relating to the borrowing of money or the giving of guarantee by the Government of Nepal, or any matter pertaining to the amendment of the Government of Nepal
What is the law with respect to any financial obligations undertaken or to be undertaken by the Government of Nepal?
The law with respect to any financial obligations undertaken or to be undertaken by the Government of Nepal is specified in clause (a).
What are the subjects specified in clause (d) of the law?

The subjects specified in clause (d) of the law are the custody and investment of all revenues received by any Federal Government Fund, moneys acquired through the repayment of loans, and grant moneys, or accounts or audits of the accounts of the Government of Nepal.
What is the provision regarding Other matters directly related to any of the subjects specified in clause (a), (b), (c) or (d)?
Other matters directly related to any of the subjects specified in clause (a), (b), (c) or (d) are also included.
What is the provision regarding Bills that provide for the levying of any charges and fees such as license fee, application fee, renewal fee or for the imposition of fines or penalty of imprisonment?
Such Bills are not deemed to be a Money Bill by the reason only that they provide for the levying of any charges and fees.
Who has the final decision on whether a Bill is a Money Bill or not?
The decision of the Speaker thereon shall be final.
What is the first step in the procedures for passage of Bills?

A Bill passed by one House of the Federal Parliament shall be transmitted to the other House of the Federal Parliament as soon as possible and such Bill, if passed by the receiving House, shall be presented to the President for assent.
What happens to a Money Bill passed by the House of Representatives?
A Money Bill passed by the House of Representatives shall be transmitted to the National Assembly.
What is the time limit for the National Assembly to send back a Money Bill with suggestions?
The National Assembly shall, after deliberations on such Bill, send back the Bill to the House of Representatives within fifteen days from the date of receipt of the Bill.
What happens to a Bill returned with suggestions by the National Assembly?
The House of Representatives shall, upon deliberations on a Bill returned with suggestions, present the Bill incorporating such suggestions as it may deem appropriate to the President for assent.
What is the final step in the procedures for passage of Bills?
The President for assent.
What happens if the National Assembly does not return a Money Bill received under clause (2) for more than fifteen days?
The House of Representatives may present the Bill to the President for assent.
What is the time limit for the National Assembly to return any Bill, except for a Money Bill, passed by the House of Representatives and transmitted to the National Assembly?
Two months from the date of receipt.
What happens if the National Assembly does not return a Bill within the specified time limit?
The House of Representatives may, by a resolution passed by a majority of the total number of its existing members, present the Bill to the President for assent.

What type of Bill can the House of Representatives present to the President for assent without the National Assembly's return if the National Assembly does not return it within the specified time limit?
Any Bill, except for a Money Bill.
What is the process for presenting a Money Bill to the President for assent if the National Assembly does not return it for more than fifteen days?
The House of Representatives may present the Bill to the President for assent.
What happens to a Bill, other than a Money Bill, passed by one House if it is rejected or passed with amendments by the other House?
The Bill shall be returned to the House where it originated.
What is the process if the House of Representatives passes a Bill which has been rejected or amended by the National Assembly under clause (6)?
If the House of Representatives passes it again as it was or with amendments, by a majority of the total number of its existing members, the Bill shall be presented to the President for assent.

What happens if a Bill which has been returned with amendments by the House of Representatives to the National Assembly under clause (6) is also again passed, with such amendments, by a majority of the number of existing members of the National Assembly?
The Bill shall be presented to the President for assent.
What type of Bills shall be referred to a joint sitting of both Houses?
The following Bills shall be referred to a joint sitting of the both Houses.

Bills which have been returned to the National Assembly with amendments by the House of Representatives, but the National Assembly has not agreed on such amendments.
What happens if the session of a House is prorogued while a Bill is under its consideration?
Deliberations on the Bill may continue at the succeeding session.

Such Bill shall lapse.

Such Bill shall lapse.
What happens to a Bill passed by the House of Representatives when it is under consideration in the National Assembly and the House of Representatives is dissolved or its term expires?
Such Bill shall lapse.
Who can withdraw a Bill?
One who has introduced a Bill may, with the approval of the House, withdraw the Bill.
What is required for a Bill to be submitted to the President for assent under Article 111?

A Bill which is to be submitted to the President for assent under Article 111 shall be so submitted by the Speaker or the Chairperson of the House in which the Bill originated after it has been certified by him or her. Provided that in the case of a Money Bill, the Speaker shall so certify.
Who certifies a Money Bill?
The Speaker shall certify a Money Bill.
How many days does the President have to assent to a Bill?
A Bill submitted to the President for his or her assent in accordance with this Article shall be assented to within fifteen days.
What happens if the President is of the opinion that any Bill, except a Money Bill, submitted for assent needs reconsideration?

If the President is of the opinion that any Bill, except a Money Bill, submitted for assent needs reconsideration, he or she may, within fifty days from the date of presentation of such Bill, return the Bill with his or her opinion.
What is the time period for a member of the House to return a Bill after its presentation?
days from the date of presentation of such Bill
Where should the Bill be returned if it is to be returned by the President?
to the House in which the Bill originated
What happens if a Bill is returned with a message by the President and both Houses reconsider and pass it again?
the President shall give assent to that Bill within fifteen days of such submission
What is the time period for the President to give assent to a Bill that has been reconsidered and passed again by both Houses?
within fifteen days of such submission
What happens if a Bill is returned with a message by the President and both Houses do not reconsider or pass it again?
Not specified in the text
What is the process for a Bill to become an Act?
A Bill shall become an Act after the President gives assent to it.
What action is required by the President for a Bill to become an Act?
The President gives assent to it for a Bill to become an Act.
What is the final step for a Bill to become an Act?
The President gives assent to it.

The President gives assent to it.
What is the role of the President in the process of a Bill becoming an Act?
The President gives assent to it.
What is the first provision relating to Ordinance?

If, at any time, except when both Houses of the Federal Parliament are in session, circumstances exist which render it necessary to take immediate action, the President may, on recommendation of the Council of Ministers, promulgate an Ordinance.
What happens to an Ordinance promulgated under clause (1) if not passed by both Houses of the Federal Parliament?
It shall ipso facto cease to be effective.
What is the effect of an Ordinance promulgated under clause (1)?
An Ordinance promulgated under clause (1) shall have the same force and effect as an Act.
What happens to an Ordinance if it is not tabled at the session of both Houses of the Federal Parliament held after the promulgation?
It shall ipso facto cease to be effective.
What can be done to repeal an Ordinance?
It may be repealed at any time by the President.
What happens to an Ordinance if it is not rendered ineffective or repealed under sub-clause (a) or (b)?

It shall, unless rendered ineffective or repealed under sub -clause (a) or (b), ipso facto cease to be effective at the expiration of sixty days after the day on which a meeting of both Houses of the Federal Parliament is held.
What does 'day on which a meeting of both Houses is held' mean?

The day on which a session or meeting of both Houses of the Federal Parliament commences or is held, and this term means the later day on which a meeting of the House is held if the Houses of the Federal Parliament meet on different dates.
What is the meaning of'session or meeting of both Houses of the Federal Parliament'?

Sixty days after the day on which a meeting of both Houses is held.

The term 'day on which a meeting of both Houses is held' means the later day on which a meeting of the House is held if the Houses of the Federal Parliament meet on different dates.
What is the significance of the term 'later day on which a meeting of the House is held'?
It refers to the day on which a meeting of the House is held if the Houses of the Federal Parliament meet on different dates.

Federal Consolidated Fund

Revenues of trusts ( Guthi)

All loans raised on the security of revenues

Any other moneys received by the Government of Nepal in repayment of any loans made under the authority of any Act

What is the entity responsible for laying an annual estimate for every financial year?
The Minister for Finance of the Government of Nepal
What are the three matters that the annual estimate sets out?
an estimate of revenues, the money required to meet the charges on the Federal Consolidated Fund, and the money required to meet the expenditure to be provided for by a Federal Appropriation Act

an estimate of revenues, the money required to meet the charges on the Federal Consolidated Fund, the money required to meet the expenditure to be provided for by a Federal Appropriation Act, and a statement of the expenses allocated to every Ministry in the previous financial year and particulars of whether the objectives of the expenses have been achieved

to provide information on the expenses allocated to every Ministry in the previous financial year and whether the objectives of the expenses have been achieved

expenses

The Minister for Finance of the Government of Nepal
When is the estimate of revenues and expenditures to be laid before the Federal Parliament?
on the 15th day of Jesta (mid May) each year

an estimate of revenues and expenditures

What can the Minister for Finance of the Government of Nepal lay before the House of Representatives?

The Minister for Finance of the Government of Nepal may lay before the House of Representatives a supplementary estimate if it is found in any financial year,- (a) that the sum authorized to be spent for a particular service by the Appropriation Act for the current financial year is insufficient, or that a need has arisen for expenditures on some new service not provided for by the Appropriation Act for that year,
What are the conditions for laying a supplementary estimate?

The conditions for laying a supplementary estimate are: (a) that the sum authorized to be spent for a particular service by the Appropriation Act for the current financial year is insufficient, or (b) that a need has arisen for expenditures on some new service not provided for by the Appropriation Act for that year,
What are the two reasons for laying a supplementary estimate?

The two reasons for laying a supplementary estimate are: (a) that the sum authorized to be spent for a particular service by the Appropriation Act for the current financial year is insufficient, or (b) that a need has arisen for expenditures on some new service not provided for by the Appropriation Act for that year,
What is the purpose of a supplementary estimate?
The purpose of a supplementary estimate is to provide for additional expenditures that were not anticipated at the time of the Appropriation Act.
What is stated about the expenditures made during a financial year that exceed the amount authorized by the Appropriation Act?
The expenditures made during that financial year are in excess of the amount authorized by the Appropriation Act.
What happens to the sums included in the supplementary estimate?
The sums included in the supplementary estimate shall be specified under the related heads in a Supplementary Appropriation Bill.
What is the condition for incurring a portion of the expenditure estimated for the financial year when an Appropriation Bill is under consideration?
A portion of the expenditure estimated for the financial year may, when an Appropriation Bill is under consideration, be incurred in advance, as provided for in the Federal Act.
What is the maximum limit for the sums involved in the Vote on Account?
The expenditures incurred in accordance with the Federal Vote shall not exceed one-third of the estimate of expenditures for the financial year.
What is the condition for introducing a Vote on Account Bill?

A Vote on Account Bill shall not be introduced until the estimates of revenues and expenditures have been laid in accordance with Article 119, and the sums involved in the Vote on Account shall not exceed one-third of the estimate of expenditures for the financial year.
